Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Hierarchical Control for Large-Scale Cyber-Physical Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many complex engineering systems involve interactions among a large number of agents with coupled dynamics and decisions due to their shared environment and resources. Such systems are often operated using a hierarchical architecture, where a coordinator determines some macroscopic control signal to steer the population to achieve a desired group objective while respecting local preferences and constraints for individual agents. Examples include electricity demand response programs, ground and air transportation systems, data center power management, robotic networks, among others. The goal of this project is to establish new control and game theoretic foundations, along with numerical algorithms, to enable formal and scalable design of hierarchical population control systems.

In contrast to the existing literature that primarily focuses on static strategic agents, this project will consider both strategic and non-strategic agents with nontrivial dynamics. The project involves three tasks. (i) First, it will establish control theoretic foundations for hierarchical population control of non-strategic agents (HPCN). Each non-strategic agent is associated with a predefined local response rule and is modeled as a hybrid system. A novel approach based on abstraction of stochastic hybrid systems (SHS) will be investigated to solve the HPCN problem. (ii) The project will also develop a uniform-price dynamic mechanism design framework for hierarchical population control of strategic agents (HPCS). The framework is based the near-Nash equilibrium concept that can facilitate the analysis of the game-theoretic population behaviors. Advanced bi-level optimization algorithms will also be developed to address the computational challenges associated with the proposed mechanism design approach. (iii) The two proposed hierarchical population control frameworks will be used to study important demand response applications for the future power grid.

This research will significantly advance our understanding in complex engineering systems that involve coordination of a large population of dynamic agents. In collaboration with the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, the project is also expected to yield practical algorithms and numerical tools for the design of electricity demand response programs. Moreover, the project will impact several education activities such as use of new pedagogical tools in teaching, involvement of undergraduate students in research, and research integration with teaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates new control and game theoretic tools to enable formal and scalable design of hierarchical control systems. The project outcomes are summarized below. 

Theoretical and technical outcomes: Technical outcomes of the project involve the following three aspects:

  1. Aggregate Modeling for HPCN (hierarchical population control of non-strategic agents): We developed a general modeling framework for HPCN systems. In a HPCN system, each agent is modeled as a dynamical system under some pre-defined response rules. We propose to model such agent as a hybrid system and the overall population behavior is described by a stochastic hybrid system model.  A very general aggregate modeling framework based on stochastic hybrid systems (SHS) has been established. We derived a set of coupled PDEs and their boundary conditions that govern the evolution of the hybrid-state density function of the proposed SHS. The boundary conditions are particularly challenging to derive as the proposed SHS involves deterministic mode transitions characterized by a fairly general class of switching surfaces. Although SHS has been studied extensively in the literature, its probability density evolution cannot be explicitly characterized using the existing results, especially when there are deterministic switchings with general switching surfaces in multi-dimensional spaces. It is well known that for a standard diffusion process, the adjoint of its (strong) generator determines the form of the forward equation and the domain of the generator (indirectly) affects the boundary conditions. Unfortunately, the (strong) generator, including its domain, of a general SHS is not available in the literature. The extended generator of a generalized SHS derived in the literature cannot be directly used to obtain the forward equations either. Therefore, out SHS framework, along with the derived PDEs, contains important extensions of the existing theoretical results in the field of SHS. These studies play a fundamental role in the study of large-scale population control systems.
  2. Theory for HPCS (hierarchical population control of strategic agents): Another main focus of this project is on the hierarchical population control problem with strategic agents. In this case, the coordination strategy is essentially a mechanism that maps agents’ decisions to allocations. The mechanism couples everyone’s decision and induces a game problem among all the agents. In many CPS applications, the induced game problem is in the form of mean-field game for which the agents’ decision problems are weakly coupled. This motivated us to study mean-field games for large-population of agents. Through this project, we established a very important connection between mean field games and optimization problems in function spaces. We have shown that an important class of mean-field games is equivalent to a convex optimization problem in function spaces. We have also extended the result to nonconvex case, which is a significant result. In particular, we have shown that the mean-field game with a finite number of agents is equivalent to a (modified) social welfare optimization problem in function space. Roughly speaking, as long the as the social welfare optimization problem has strong duality property, the equivalence relation holds. We also studied the subtle differences between our equivalence result and the well-known connection between potential game and optimization.
  3. CPS Applications: On the CPS application side, we focus on developing new demand response strategies for the future power grid. We consider TCL (thermostatically controlled loads) as well as the deferrable loads. Each responsive load can be viewed as strategic or non-strategic agents depending on the types of the demand response program. For both types of loads, we developed new demand response strategies based on the developed HPCN and HPCS theory. The results have been tested on realistic simulation tools and published on top journals such as IEEE Transactions on Power Systems, IEEE Control Systems Magazine, and IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control.

 

Broader impact outcomes: First, the developed theoretical framework for hierarchical population control has been used to solve realistic demand response problems. Through collaboration with researchers at the Pacific Northwest National Lab (PNNL), we have successfully used the theory to analyze the AEP Ohio gridSMART demonstration project, and provide guidance for future improvements on real demand response programs. Second, the results of this project have been disseminated through several conference and journal publications, including the IEEE Conference on Decision and Control, Midwest Workshop on Control and Game Theory, the 4th Workshop on Information Modeling, Analysis and Control, the 57th Annual Allerton Conference on Communication, Control, and Computing,  IEEE Transactions on Power Systems, Automatica, IEEE Control Systems Magazine, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control,  etc. Third, the project has also involved several education activities, including developing new course (e.g Hybrid Systems and Introduction to Robotics), supporting a MS Fulbright Fellow (Guillermo Castillo) from Ecuador, supporting graduate students to visit other top universities. Two of the PhD students supported by this project have recently got tenure-track faculty positions in the area of cyber-physical systems.
